command: pktmon filter remove; pktmon filter add -t UDP -p 9; pktmon start --capture --pkt-size 0 --file-name C:\Temp\wol_capture.etl
explanation: Starts Packet Monitor (requires Administrator/UAC) to sniff for UDP port 9 traffic associated with WOL magic packets, supporting reconnaissance for signaling. Detection: monitor privileged packet capture usage (pktmon start) and correlate with sudden capture file creation.
rationale_steps: Clear existing pktmon filters and add a UDP/9 filter.
Begin a live capture to an ETL file to observe magic packets.
Administrative privileges required; UAC prompt likely when starting capture.
Detect via audit of pktmon execution and filesystem events for capture artifacts.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Uses valid PowerShell semicolons and recognized pktmon flags (-t UDP, -p 9, --capture, --pkt-size 0, --file-name) with a valid Windows path and no quoting required.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: If run elevated, it clears filters, adds a UDP/9 filter, and starts full packet capture to the specified ETL supporting reconnaissance for signaling, but it requires admin rights and the C:\Temp directory to exist.
